awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Urban Flooding and Residential Adaptation
awd_abstract_narration:
Of all natural hazards, flooding exerts the greatest economic and social impacts on the US population, and its impacts have increased over time. In response, the US government is funding the voluntary acquisition of homes in floodplains across the country, removing people and homes from the nation’s most flood-prone areas. This project advances scientific understanding of managed retreat from American floodplains, including their impacts on different types of communities. Results provide decisionmakers, floodplain managers, and community leaders with state-of-the-art knowledge needed to make flood adaption more socially and administratively successful in the future.

This project investigates tens of thousands of households nationwide who have exited, stayed, and entered neighborhoods targeted by the federal government’s policy of managed retreat. The project leverages novel sources of data to follow the residential trajectories of participants and non-participants to and from neighborhoods targeted for managed retreat over time. Sources will include individual-level data on residential histories, address-level data on future flood risks, and longitudinal household survey and interview data. The study also accounts for the different types of communities in which households are embedded. Results contribute to understanding of residential mobility as a form of flood adaptation and how managed retreat unfolds differently for different populations facing increasing flood risks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In the NSF-funded project "Urban Flooding and Residential Adaptation," Primary Investigators James R. Elliott (Rice University) and Kevin Loughran (Temple University) have studied the social dimensions of urban flooding in the US, especially current federal policies that are funding the retreat of people and housing from areas of increasing risk in hopes of creating more resilient cities. Central to those policy efforts are payments to homeowners to voluntarily give up their housing for demolition and move elsewhere. Such policies aim to eliminate risk by returning the purchased parcels to their prior undeveloped state, never to be built-on again except possibly for flood mitigation infrastructure. This study has improved scientific understanding of the social dynamics of managed retreat by advancing a nationwide, population-centered investigation of their unfolding across diverse urban populations, including non-participants who remain in or exit targeted neighborhoods. This study is the first to offer a national longitudinal assessment of the residential trajectories of the people and places involved in managed retreat as well as how their experiences and perceptions vary by the racial contexts in which they occur.

This pathbreaking work used a mixed-methods design with the following objectives: First, the PIs acquired, validated, and merged consumer data, including individual residential histories, for all households moving to, from, and within neighborhoods of managed retreat from 1990 to the present. Second, the PIs used those data to distinguish what happens residentially to participating and nonparticipating households from what happens over time to targeted neighborhoods and the local resettlement systems in which they are embedded. Third, the PIs conducted stratified random surveys to quantitatively identify and assess the multiple forms and directions those residential trajectories take for different groups as well as their impacts and implications for neighborhoods of origin and destination. Finally, the PIs strategically interviewed households to deepen knowledge of how that diversity of experience intersects with perceptions of local flood risk, neighborhood quality, sense of community, and notions of "ideal" forms of adaptation for different social groups and neighborhoods.

Results have increased understanding of how households and neighborhoods are adapting to rising flood risks within racially stratified cities. Results have also advanced knowledge in areas of urban sociology concerned with residential mobility and racial inequities, while strengthening engagement with environmental sociology and convergent, multidisciplinary research on urban flooding and natural disasters more generally. As the results continue to be disseminated, those contributions to basic science will inform applied urban, housing, and disaster policy at the local, state, and federal levels by contributing to data-driven decision-making that recognizes the role that equity plays in long-term community adaptation.
